column1: The women went away.... And now
column3: royal Odysseus washed his skin clean of the salt which clung about his back and his broad shoulders
column4: and wiped from his head the foam brought by the barren sea; and when he had thoroughly bathed and oiled himself and had put on the clothing which the chaste maiden gave
column7: made him taller than before and stouter to behold
column8: and she made the curling locks to fall around his head as on the hyacinth flower. As when a man lays gold on silver
column9: —some skillful man whom Hephaestus and Pallas Athene have trained in every art
column10: and he fashions graceful work; so did she cast a grace upon his head and shoulders. He walked apart along the shore
